content.value: Making games is hard work. Really hard work. Videogames are not simple things to create. Videogames are incredibly complex machines and can very easily stop working at pretty much any point in their construction. One moment, everything is going smoothly, the next, Joe Danger's leg is getting trapped in the geometry of a sentient, talking mole, sending him pinging forty eight billion miles into the distance (much to the amusement of everyone except code monster Dave Ream, whose job it was to fix it).

I don't claim to have gained any technical knowledge during my time with Hello Games; after all, that was not the purpose of documenting this studio. What I did see was the sheer effort involved in creating a game, etched in the furrowed brows of concentration; reflected in the weary, reddened eyes brought about by crunch days.

There's that dreaded word: crunch. There has been a fair amount of media coverage concerning the downside of crunch in recent years, and deservedly so, but crunch is different in a smaller company like this. In very large companies, crunch can be ruinous to peoples' lives, consisting of compulsory overnight working sessions that sometimes last for weeks. At Hello Games, it felt different.

Now I'm not saying everyone was jumping for joy when they discovered they wouldn't get to go home at a reasonable hour that day, but compared to the horror stories we've heard of in large-scale game studios, the concept of crunch was completely different. This is a studio whose size means that everyone had a significant personal investment and involvement in the game; that sense of ownership creates a positive atmosphere and changes the long, hardworking nights into something that feels worthwhile and satisfying. Your boss is a lot more visible, too, so instead of having this unreasonable directive from an invisible higher power, you can nip over to the adjacent desk and say 'Sean, I'm going to go home'.
In short, this section is all about stress, collaboration, bonding, more stress, relief and, most importantly, ice cream.

Now this is game development. Like true professionals, the moment the ice cream van's jingle tinkled through the studio, everyone leapt to their feet and sprinted outside. Even with deadlines fast approaching, it's important to find time for ice cream.

Here we see the usual handiwork of Jake, using his artistic abilities to motivate the team by sketching deeply upsetting caricatures. In this image, Jake has made the bold decision to represent Sean as a sort of moustachioed evil ringmaster.

Once again, Jake uses his caricatures to motivate and inspire. Here we see a placeholder image Jake has created which depicts the likeness of junior artist Aaron. This handy caricature reminds Aaron that he still hasn't finished the overdue art asset that should feature on this loading screen; it's simultaneously motivational and instructional.

In this meeting, Dave, Grant, Alex and Jake hang on Sean's every word. Dave is so enthralled here that he is actively holding his eyelids open to ensure no scrap of visual information goes unconsumed.
